result.markdown: --- title: "R blog with quarto" description: | Switching from distill to quarto and successfully contributing to R-bloggers. date: "2022-06-01" date-format: "YYYY-MM-DD" categories: [R] image: "thumbnail.png" cap-location: margin draft: true --- ::: callout-note ## Summary TBD ::: ## Background I have blogged intermittently since 2014. My original blog was in WordPress with the beautiful and sparse [tru](https://tru.spyr.me/) theme. Writing prose and including images was not difficult, but including R code was clunky at best. And I was unable to resolve the issues that prevented my blog from being included in [R-bloggers](https://www.r-bloggers.com/). When I discovered the [distill](https://rstudio.github.io/distill/) package, I drafted some blog posts in rmarkdown and published on GitHub pages. There were some bumpy spots and workarounds, but creating R-focused posts was straightforward and comfortable given my experience with reproducible authoring using rmarkdown, knitr, etc. As an aside, I experimented with [blogdown](https://pkgs.rstudio.com/blogdown/) at the same time I tried distill. I'm certain that blogdown works beautifully for many folks, but for me, distill took me farther faster with fewer hangups. I enjoyed writing with distill. The only significant issue was, again, an inability to create a full RSS feed suitable for submitting to R-bloggers ([#376](https://github.com/rstudio/distill/issues/376)). Looking for suggestions on fixing the RSS feed, I came across a similar discussion on a quarto page. One of the contributors (thanks [Bryan](https://github.com/bryanhanson)!) had a distill workaround but suggested I take a look at quarto. I did. He was right. Eventually---with some expeditious bug fixing ([#946](https://github.com/quarto-dev/quarto-cli/discussions/946))---I could use [quarto](https://quarto.org/) to create a blog (this site) that met the requirements for aggregation on R-bloggers. ## Get started with quarto The getting started with quarto guidelines have been done. I'll just point you to the readings I found helpful. - [We don't talk about Quarto](https://www.apreshill.com/blog/2022-04-we-dont-talk-about-quarto/) by Alison Hill - [Porting a distill blog to quarto](https://blog.djnavarro.net/posts/2022-04-20_porting-to-quarto/) by Danielle Navarro - [Notes on changing from Rmarkdown/Bookdown to Quarto](https://www.njtierney.com/post/2022/04/11/rmd-to-qmd/) by Nick Tierney - [Get started](https://quarto.org/docs/get-started/) on the quarto website The quarto features I like, compared to distill, are - `_metadata.yml` for applying settings to all posts, shortening the YAML header of individual posts - `_quarto.yml` with the usual website organization structure plus additional formatting applied to all posts - Full RSS feed with categories and an XML file that passes muster with an RSS feed checker. ## The niggles
